titleStmt.title: Punch to the Ladies his Petition

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Quid non Mortalia pectora cogis auri
Fair ones to you, who, hearts command
and gently sway with Fan in hand
your favourite Punch a Suplṭ falls
and humbly for Assistance calls,
He humbly calls and begs you'l stop
the Gothick Rage of vandor Hop:
wh'invades without pretence or right
or any Law but that of Might,
our Pigmy Land──and treats our kings
like paultry, idle, wooden things
has beat our Dancers out of doors,
and call'd our chastest Virgins, whores,
he has not left our Queen a rag on
and forc'd our George away & dragon
has broke our wyres nor was he civil
to Doctor Faustus & the Devil;
E'en me he hurry'd with fell rage
most hoarsly squaling of the stage
and faith our Fright was very great
to see a Minister of state
arm'd with power & fury come
to force us from our little home
we fear'd as I'm sure we'd Reason
an accusation of high-treasontill starting up says Benameer
treason my friends we need not fear
for 'gainst the brass we us'd no pow'r
nor strove to save the Chancellour;
nor did we shew the least affection
to Rochfort on Westmeath Election;
nor did we sing Mc̣Cue─────
the villain I'll dash out thy brains,
'tis no affair of state that brings
me here, nor business of the King's
I'm come to seize on all as Debtors
and bind you fast in Jron fetters
from sight of ev'ry friend in Town
'till fifty pound to me's laid down.fifty quoth I, a develish sum
but stay till the new halfpence come
then we shall be rich as jews
from Castletown to lowest Stews
that Sum to you shall then be told
tho: now we cannot furnish Gold.quoth he thou lovest Punch to prate
and woud'st for ever hold debate
but thinkest thou I have nought to doe
but thus to argue still with you,
or dost thou think yt I am come
to carry nought but farthings home;
thou fool, I ne'er do things by halves
Farthings were made for Irish slaves;
no brass for me, it must be Gold
or fifty pound in silver told
that can by any mean's obtaine
Freedom for thee or for thy train.votre tres humble Servitieur
I'm not in jest said I, J'm sure
but from the bottom of my Belly
in sober Sadness J must tell yẹ
I think it is good reas'ning
that we fictitious men shou'd bring
brass Counters made by William Wood
which might as well be understood
right sterling as we flesh & blood
and since we are but mimick men
pray let us pay in mimick Coin.add too, 'tis said that you and I
are of the self same family;
and faith I'm apt to think so too,
for who is liker me than you;
just the same grave and awkard grace
shews forth it self in either face,
and each of us with labour struts
behind a flasket huge with Gutts;
we tally well in these respects,
but best of all in Jntellects;
for when you took the Difference learn'd
'twixt the words sorry, & concern'd,
and when upon a grave affair,
amaz'd you gaz'd behind a Chair
then cry'd──Lord, how like punchenello
is that same fat, beefwitted fellow,
then prithee Cousin let us buss
and cease to treat your kindred thusQuoth he thou vile mishapen beast,
thou knave, am I become thy jest,
now not a Puppet of yẉ all,
shall stir a step without this Wall;
nor Merry Andrew beat thy Drum
untill you pay th' overe afforesaid Sum.then marching off with solemn pace
to write dispatches for his G──ce
the R──ll master left the Room
and us condemn'd to fatall do
Now fair ones, if I e're found grace
or if my jokes did ever please,
use all your Interest with the Sec:
they say he's at the Lady's beck
and tho: he thirsts as much for Gold
as ever Mydas did of old,
your Charms I'm sure can never faile
your Eyes must Jnfluence prevail
at your Commd
he'el set us free
let us to you owe Liberty;
get us a Licence now to play,
and (as in duty bound) we'el pray
